from Prof. Krugman:
"...political virtue consists in standing for what's right..."

indeed...
as Robert F Kennedy once told a group of young people in South Africa in 1966:
( in part ):

"There is discrimination in this world and slavery and slaughter and starvation. Governments repress their people; millions are trapped in poverty while the nation grows rich and wealth is lavished on armaments everywhere. These are differing evils, but they are the common works of man. They reflect the imperfection of human justice, the inadequacy of human compassion, our lack of sensibility towards the suffering of our fellows. But we can perhaps remember -- even if only for a time -- that those who live with us are our brothers; that they share with us the same short moment of life; that they seek -- as we do -- nothing but the chance to live out their lives in purpose and happiness, winning what satisfaction and fulfillment they can.
...
Few are willing to brave the disapproval of their fellows, the censure of their colleagues, the wrath of their society. Moral courage is a rarer commodity than bravery in battle or great intelligence. Yet it is the one essential, vital quality for those who seek to change a world that yields most painfully to change. And I believe that in this generation those with the courage to enter the moral conflict will find themselves with companions in every corner of the globe."
...
much more: http://www.americanrhetoric.com/speeches/ekennedytributetorfk.html

Mitra:

"You show me another country where contacting a woman more than once when she has clearly indicated disinterest is a criminal offense for which a person can be sent to jail for seven years and then we will discuss, OK?"

A man contacts a woman, she says "I am not interested", he contacts her one more time and is sent to jail for seven years? No Freaking Way.

This kind of hyperbole is exactly why your concerns are being ignored.

@Laura

That is what Indian law says- what we are debating is whether it is a good law or whether the language of the law makes it very likely for it to be abused. My concerns are "ignored" by Americans, not Indians - by people who have been taught certain things about Indian society and who repeat them like a mantra without trying to understand or know much. As I said, the less a western person knows about India, the more certain they are about their shallow opinions. Certainty is proportional to ignorance. To all the western people commenting here- what you don't know about India vastly exceeds what you do, so please have some humility.

Mitra-if someone says "leave me alone" WHY ARE YOU STILL CONTACTING HER?

That is what the problem is-sometimes you have to be super harsh to get the message through some insanely thick skulls.

Why should she have to change her number, get a new phone, do anything when he is the one who should stop?

She should ruin his life. He is trying to ruin hers.

Thanks! I am glad there are still people who are using their brains for thinking!  Demagougery and slogan shouting seems to have replaced any kind of reasoned dialogue in both United States and India.The only important question is which side you are on - the content of your argument, the extent of your understanding or knowledge is not considered important. Add to this the simplistic and exaggerated ideas about Indian society that most  Americans have and then you get the kind of shallow moral posturing and noise that we see on the comments page here. People who know nothing about an issue are still rushing to comment and are full of a sense of self righteousness because they believe they are on the right side and the people who diagree with them are evil. The quality of our public debate is such that we are good at trading insults, but dialogue of any kind (which requires the capacity to respectfully disagree and engage in civil debate, not name calling) is becoming rare. The situation is worse in India becaue people care even less about facts and evidence than in USA (hard to believe but true!), and define their positions on an issue solely based on their political and ideological inclinations. The only mode of public debate and engagement is sloganeering and shouting /screaming and name calling the other side- no wonder United States (and of course India) cannot even come anywhere close to tackling the major challenges they face.

India is hated by every one of its neighbours. As a diplomat (CIA) friend once mentioned to me in an aside at a Nairobi party in 1998, "India has no friends. Not even its own educated and cultured citizens or impoverished serfs. Put that in your pipe and smoke it".

@Seth

We have a few disagreements on some of your specific points, but I was amused by your comment on know-it-all tinted glasses. From my experience of living in the West, I have found that the LESS some Western people know about India, the more confident they are in expressing their views! Certainly is proportional to ignorance - some philosophers of knowledge may not be surprised! After all, real knowledge, if it existed would have come with some degree of humility and more willingess to learn from others. It is also relevant that the West still controls/shapes the global media. So even Indian journalists working here have to conform to norms dictated by international media - Indian women have to be projected as hapless victims of a reign of terror/patriarchy etc. Many intelligent and confident Indian women have told me that they are revoled by the kind of stereotypes that Western men/women have about them - pitying them and expecting them to be submissive/obedient/ exotic etc etc. If an Indian journalist in USA wanted to do a story on the abuse of 498A/304B or the progress of women and women leaders in India, the editors would reject his story because it would cause discomfiture among Western readers. (The Economist magazine is a rare Western publication which has balanced coverage of Indian politics and society). As the great economist William Easterly observes, such paternalism and condescension also has a negative impact on Western approaches to foreign aid.

Great comment. However, Citizens United was the result of our corrupted mindset, that the electorate was so swayed by the Gingrich/Starr agenda, which became the Republican Tea Party, as to vote against their own interest in the near election and swift boat reelection of W.

The authors are talking about a catastrophic event like the racial strife in what is now Bosnia (that'll never happen again...) that led to world war 1 or the crippling monetary policies inflicted on countries in central Europe (likewise that's absurd, could never happen now).

The authors say that the continuance of the estate tax "requires dramatic external events" for proponents of progressive taxation to recast the debate, and that "an economic crisis could constitute such a new event." But they don't seem to recognize or acknowledge that we have, indeed,  had exactly such a crisis ongoing since the crash of 2008. The vast majority of the population has suffered greatly by virtue of high unemployment, reduction of Federal unemployment benefits, home foreclosures, a massive increase in student debt, and a loss of interest income by savers and the elderly, while Wall Street and the banks have rebounded. But perhaps worst of all, the Citizens United decision has corrupted our democracy and led to inordinate political influence by the wealthy, the banks, and the corporations, not to mention losses in worker protections and collective bargaining rights. And now the representatives of the wealthy are looking to further harm the middle class by going after Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, while Mitt Romney and his ilk continue to avoid paying taxes on their assets in the Cayman Islands. That seems to me to be a crises of sufficient proportions to justify a continuation and expansion of the estate tax.

Lincoln did not "send 700,000 men to their deaths."   260,000 of the dead were Confederates.  Two thirds of all deaths were due to illness.  Only a small number of Union soldiers were conscripts, and they tended to be scorned and shunned by the volunteers.

BOQ,

The next time we are geehawed here in the U.S. in a major way, I don't think we'll be prepared for it.

-Kiki

As far as I can tell, haw is "here," i.e. turn toward the farmer, and "gee" is get (away); the opposite.  Since the farmer stands to the left of the oxen in American, haw is a left turn, but in England and some other places, the farmer stands to the right, so the opposite is true.
What do non-English-speaking oxen do?

GEE WHIZ! Neither constructor would make a good draft animal. GEE is right not left. A regular expert at turning left would be a haw whiz!

-Kiki

I can always tell when an Estate is set up to be costly on the other end at death. Clients go through these huge costs to set up an Estate plan and then the Lawyer(s) neglect to tell them to follow through on their recommendations. I only know this for I am there when the elderly person dies, and the kids ask me the financial advisor, didn't mom and dad have all this put in place? Estate settlement is not that difficult if assets are titled properly. Those are the smoothest Estates to settle. Law firms have great pleasure in billing the max on uninformed individuals.

I got my first lesson when at a young age I was appointed an Executor and had my first encounter with a Law Firm. I remember the Lawyer settling the Estate called and asked if I was free for lunch. I attend the Lunch at the luxurious law firms private dining room, spent 3 hours with the Attorney settling the Estate, and one week later received an $600 bill. I called to ask what this bill was for, and when I stated to him, you had called me and asked me if I was free for lunch, and he said, yes, but I didn't say the lunch was for free.

Nah. Any lawyer who tries to charge for time to bill should be reported to the respective bar association. Nobody gets to bill for time spent to bill. You got it wrong or didn't understand. $5/page? You could have contested. What did the contract say? Somebody signed a contract. This comment lacks credibility.
Sounds like the Wills and Trusts department of the law firm I did proofreading for in the mid-1980s.  We figured the clients wound up in the charity nursing home and their heirs in the poorhouse.

When my father-in-law died 12 years ago, he had appointed as executor of his estate the law firm that had drawn up the will and trust instruments. Their bill was outrageous and when an itemized bill was requested, we were told that preparing it would be tens of thousands of dollars. We didn't wish to further deplete the estate, so they had us. We did discover that in addition to the lawyer, he added a second lawyer and a paralegal to the case - yet more expense. They also billed $5 per page for any document they sent us. My father-in-law wasn't a Rockefeller and the estate wasn't particularly complicated. But the fees to file the state and federal tax returns were enormous.

Between the law firm's bill and the 57% estate tax paid at that time, our inheritance was greatly reduced. As my late husband was a school teacher, I'm grateful we got anything - it was far more a matter if what was taken from the estate by others.

Also, Nicosia and Moscow are separated by only four degrees of longitude. Approximately 29 degrees of longitude separate Nicosia and Brussels.

Everything one needs to know is right here. The rounding up (.75/hour to .8), and learning on the job (calling the clerk) charged to the client. And what was your hourly rate? And how many years have you practiced and what are you paid?
At either of my two old firms, your work would have been done by an experienced secretary and paralegal, both under the supervision of a lawyer, both charging time into the client. Duplication, supervision can only be justified when it results in a lower charge, but either method can generate outrageous fees.
How does any firm justify its fees? Isn't the question one of value to the client, not the value to the firm?
You are supposed to bill for all the time you talk to the client.
Boo hoo. And how much did you bill for that 0.8 hour?  $300?  $500?  Let's get real.  Lawyers are the most overpaid cockroaches after WS Banksters.

I was in a big law firm and I had a very big client.  Kind of on a whim, the client decided to pursue a claim for intellectual property in a bankruptcy matter.   I had bankruptcy experience, took the matter on, I drafted a proof of claim, looked at the Bankruptcy rules, then called the Bankruptcy clerk of court to be sure I understood a filing issue properly.  I finalized the proof of claim and had it filed.  For this entire operation I billed for 45 minutes, or .8 of an hour.  The client had a fit that I took so long and I ended up on the phone for over an hour, for which I did not bill for or get paid for, to explain my 45 minutes.  There is nothing worse than working in a big firm.  Nothing.

We provide the aid in order to buy Egypt's official non-hostility (not friendship) toward Israel; and have done so ever since the Camp David peace treaty over 30 years ago. That's why Egypt, out of all countries, is always the #2 recipient of U.S. foreign aid; Israel of course is always #1. A tiny, tiny number of people are actual, verifiable "super tasters".

The rest are just spoiled brats, whose parents indulged their whims. In poor third world societies, there are no "super tasters" because you'd starve to death if you didn't eat what was offered or available.

Do you think poor peasants, or struggling subsistence farmers in the sub-Sahara, cook packaged mac n cheese, because "that's all their kids will eat"?

American kids are SUPER spoiled, arrogant and demanding -- because we permit them to be that way.

Concerned--I am so with you. If kids get used to calling the shots as to what's on the table, they will abuse it.

One memory regarding food still rings in my mind. My paternal grandmother (who spent a good stretch of WWII in a DP camp) had made green linguine as a side dish (as opposed to the regular white type, which I loved when my Mom made it with loads of garlic). Before trying it, I said I "hated" it (cut me some slack here, this was before I turned 3). In retrospect, I was probably acting out because Mom and Dad were away for the weekend. Her words to me then?

"Jen, NEVER say you hate food. You may have to go hungry one day. You're allowed not to LIKE something, but never say you HATE food that you can actually eat. Also, try it. It may not be your favorite (meaning my Mom's supergarlic linguine) but you may like it anyway."

Stunned, I let her put it on my plate, and guess what, it was good and I ate it. And I never DIDN'T try something for the rest of my natural life to date, and it has paid off richly.

You can't force kids to eat, but you don't have to provide a carte-blanche system of backup foods either. At any time growing up, if I had said that I wanted something else from the fridge other than what was for dinner, I think the answer would have been stunned silence.

Your friends who eat only white foods might be super-tasters.  Super-tasters have exponentially more taste buds than the average person, so their eating habits are not just a matter of pickiness, unadventurous mindsets, or childishness.  They are extremely sensitive to flavor and actually taste food differently than "regular" tasters.  Often they've faced a lot of embarrassment over the issue, and they worry about things like eating out at unfamiliar restaurants, the cuisine available while traveling, insulting their hosts by not finishing their food, and so on.

Decades ago when I worked in a residential treatment center for children, long before our current pharmacopia  for behavioral management, I cooked cream of wheat almost identically to your rice pudding. You wouldn't believe with what alacrity beds were made and hair combed for the prospect of my hot cream of wheat. All it took was a gentle reminder of the logical consequence of requiring me to umpire their morning squabbles would be that I couldn't be in the kitchen cooking their beloved cream of wheat. Reward and peer pressure did the trick!
I love pickled beets.

There were 7 children at our table and we ate pretty much whatever was put in front of us. Minnesota, so a lot of it was totally white food. We also ate beets, tomatoes, chard, green beans, asparagus, cucumbers, corn, and lettuce from a large garden. Fruits in season.

I have no idea why we weren't picky eaters. There was little resistance to any particular food that I can remember. Meals were pretty peaceful. We remained tolerant eaters and none of us had weight problems until several decades later (mostly me and a brother).

Mostly I think picky eaters (on into adulthood, sometimes) are just missing out on a lot of pleasures.

The point of labeling in a restaurant is because patrons don't know the full ingredient list. A recipe is, by definition, the full ingredient list. How hard is it to google the components of a recipe and come up with a nutritional breakdown?

Hint: really, really easy.
Your lousy eating habits are not my problem.
